content: Added "write UNSTABLE" to stub generator so that the initial default code shows the syntax for debugging and outputting the answer.

Changed the wording a bit (Exemple -> Example, if a card fall down -> ...can fall down).

I think you should explain the conditions for an unstable card more detailed, as I had to look at the examples to understand the rules:
A card is unstable, if
- neither another card nor the ground are below it
- the card below has the same orientation
- there is no card next to it in the falling direction, that pushes against it

by the way, //\ is unstable, isn't it? I didn't see that in the testcases.
This puzzle is ok for me. I enjoyed it very much :)

Solution inspired by R4N4R4M4 for his beautiful idea !
Thanks man ! :thumbsup:
Agree with the comment entirely. Mind adding more test cases?
I think we should add the //\ test (/\\ as validator). By now I'm not 100% sure, if this is considered unstable.

Yup, I'm gonna make more edgy test cases (like the one you said)
Thanks ! :thumbsup:

I can't think of a reasonable way to express this problem's physics if this is stable. Two subsequent cards in same orientation are apart by half an arch-width, so one of them necessarily can't have support.

Making that case stable would need (for example) declaring them to be touching by an entire plane, which in turns needs to either have them almost an entire half-arch *thick*, or to declare the input diagram non-constant-width.
Neither of which fits the visuals.

The card would fall a bit, but not completely when hitting its stable neighbor, so metastable.
I would call it unstable. But for this kind of changes I prefer to discuss and let the creator of the puzzle make the final decission (while I edit grammar mistakes myself, if I am sure about it).

- Statement edited to be clearer about if a card structure is unstable.
- Fixed one test and one validator (forgot their names) where one dot on a line at the end was missing.
- Added 5 tests cases about '//\' and original tests (and because 42 :p).
-Edited my own solution, I didn't handle some special cases I have added

I'm sure the statement needs to be remodified a bit though, don't hesitate to edit it if something needs more clarity or if there are syntax issues.
Added a sentence about the stability of the total structure. I will write my own solution later and validate the puzzle, if my code passes all tests.
